study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of piperine as a treatment for PCOS by analyzing its binding interactions with key molecular targets implicated in PCOS pathogenesis.
results_summary: The study found favorable binding affinities between piperine and key PCOS-related genes (PPARG and H6PD), suggesting its potential to modulate these targets. Molecular simulations supported the reliability of these interactions, indicating piperine's therapeutic promise for PCOS.
population_specificity: Women with PCOS (computational study, no human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether piperine (PIP) could enhance the sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cells to doxorubicin (DOX) by targeting the PI3K/Akt/mTOR pathway and cancer stem cells (CSCs).
results_summary: The study found that PIP synergistically enhanced DOX's effect on TNBC cells, suppressing the PI3K/Akt/mTOR pathway and reducing CSC markers like ALDH-1. In vivo results showed increased tumor necrosis and downregulation of key resistance-related proteins, suggesting PIP may reduce DOX resistance.
population_specificity: Triple-negative breast cancer (MDA-MB-231 cell line) and Ehrlich ascites carcinoma solid tumor model in animals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of piperine, alone and combined with aerobic exercise, against paraquat-induced lung damage in rats.
results_summary: Piperine significantly reduced oxidative stress, inflammation, and histopathological damage in lung tissue, with stronger effects when combined with exercise training compared to exercise alone. The combination of piperine and exercise showed comparable or superior protective effects to vitamin E, a positive control.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (230 g, 6-8 weeks old)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piperine, when combined with curcumin, could improve oxidative stress markers, fecal calprotectin, and pro-inflammatory cytokines in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: The study found that curcumin plus piperine significantly increased serum superoxide dismutase (SOD) levels compared to placebo, but no significant differences were observed in fecal calprotectin, inflammatory markers, or other oxidative stress indicators.
population_specificity: Adults (≥18 years) with Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis and intact liver/kidney function.
effective_dosage: 10 mg/day of piperine combined with 1000 mg/day of curcumin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a stable piperine-loaded nanoemulsion to enhance its solubility and evaluate its antifungal efficacy against Candida spp. compared to pure piperine in DMSO.
results_summary: The study found that the piperine-loaded nanoemulsion had significantly enhanced antifungal activity, with MIC90 values 20-50% lower than pure piperine in DMSO, and demonstrated stability with no observable physical changes. The nanoemulsion showed consistent efficacy across all tested Candida spp.
population_specificity: Candida spp. (including C. albicans and C. glabrata) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if co-loading Piperine (PIP) with Resveratrol (RSV) in phytosomes enhances pharmacokinetic properties and cardioprotective effects in myocardial infarction (MI).
results_summary: The study found that RSV phytosomes co-loaded with PIP (RPP) significantly improved heart rate, ECG, biomarker levels, and antioxidant activity in MI-induced rats, with prolonged systemic circulation (>24h) compared to free drugs.
population_specificity: Isoproterenol-induced myocardial infarction rats and healthy Wistar rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Piperine's effects on ARL3 expression, cell proliferation, EMT, and ER stress in colorectal adenocarcinoma (COAD) cells.
results_summary: Piperine inhibited COAD cell proliferation, induced apoptosis, downregulated ARL3 expression, suppressed EMT, and attenuated ER stress responses. These effects suggest Piperine has anti-cancer potential in COAD.
population_specificity: Colorectal adenocarcinoma (COAD) cells in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the molecular mechanisms of piperine's antitumor effects in colorectal cancer (CRC) cells, focusing on autophagy, ROS accumulation, and AKT/mTOR pathway inhibition.
results_summary: Piperine inhibited CRC cell viability and tumor growth in a mouse model by inducing autophagy-dependent cell death, increasing ROS production, and suppressing AKT/mTOR signaling. Activation of AKT or ROS clearance attenuated these effects.
population_specificity: Human colorectal cancer cells (in vitro) and a xenograft tumor mouse model using CT26 cells (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial, antioxidant, and anticancer properties of piperine-coated zinc oxide nanoparticles (ZnO-PIP NPs) against dental pathogens and oral cancer cells.
results_summary: ZnO-PIP NPs demonstrated significant antioxidant activity, strong antimicrobial effects (MIC of 50 µg/mL), and dose-dependent anticancer activity on KB oral squamous carcinoma cells, upregulating apoptotic genes.
population_specificity: Dental pathogens and KB oral squamous carcinoma cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: MIC of 50 µg/mL (antimicrobial testing); anticancer testing was dose-dependent but specific dosages not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of a curcumin-piperine combination on cyclophosphamide-induced brain damage in rats by measuring biochemical and histopathological parameters.
results_summary: The study found that the curcumin-piperine combination reduced oxidative stress and inflammatory markers (8-OHdG, NO, IL-6, NF-kβ, MDA, TNF-α) and increased antioxidant levels (SOD, CAT, GPx, GSH) in CP-treated rats, but did not significantly affect pTAU, Aβ1-42, GLU, or GABA levels.
population_specificity: Rats treated with cyclophosphamide (CP) to induce brain damage.
effective_dosage: 200 or 300 mg/kg CUR-PP via oral gavage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piperine enhances the sensitivity of prostate cancer cells to docetaxel (DTX) and elucidate its mechanism of action, particularly focusing on the Notch signaling pathway.
results_summary: Piperine reduced cell viability, induced apoptosis, and inhibited migration and invasion in both DTX-sensitive and DTX-resistant prostate cancer cells. It also downregulated the Notch signaling pathway by inhibiting Notch1 and Jagged1 and reducing downstream effector expression.
population_specificity: DTX-resistant prostate cancer cell line (DU145/DTX) and its DTX-sensitive counterpart (DU145).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of curcumin-piperine supplementation on inflammatory markers, antioxidant capacity, and clinical outcomes in patients who underwent CABG surgery.
results_summary: The study found that curcumin-piperine significantly reduced CRP levels and increased TAC, with marginal reductions in CK-MB, but no significant effects on troponin I, LDH, ejection fraction, or arterial fibrillation.
population_specificity: Adults who underwent CABG surgery (n=80).
effective_dosage: 500 mg curcumin + 5 mg piperine per tablet, administered as 1-3 tablets daily (5-15 mg piperine/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of curcumin and piperine supplementation on glycemic parameters (FPG, HOMA-IR, BMI) in patients with prediabetes and type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found mixed results, with two studies showing no significant difference in outcomes between the supplement and placebo groups, while one study reported a significant reduction in BMI. Meta-analysis indicated numerical but non-significant improvements in FPG, HOMA-IR, and BMI.
population_specificity: Patients with prediabetes and type 2 diabetes mellitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding piperine to a curcumin patch enhances its analgesic effects in managing acute postoperative orofacial pain.
results_summary: The study found no significant additional benefit from piperine when combined with curcumin patches compared to curcumin alone, though within-group comparisons showed some pain reduction. Salivary PGE2 levels indicated differences between piperine and non-piperine groups, but overall group comparisons were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 75 patients who underwent oromaxillofacial surgery at Unpad Dental Hospital, Bandung, Indonesia.
study_duration: Evaluated at two time points eight hours apart.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of piperine in combination with curcumin and taurine as an adjuvant therapy to enhance immune response and improve clinical outcomes in HCC patients treated with TACE.
results_summary: The study found that the combination therapy significantly increased serum IFN-γ levels, downregulated PD-1 expression in MNLs, and reduced CD4+CD25+ regulatory T lymphocytes, alongside improvements in AST, LDH, and AFP levels.
population_specificity: 20 TACE-treated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of curcuminoids (with piperine) on oxidative stress and antioxidant capacity in girls with premenstrual syndrome (PMS) and dysmenorrhea.
results_summary: The study found that curcuminoids (with piperine) significantly increased free-radical scavenging activity in serum compared to placebo, but no significant changes were observed in other oxidative stress markers. The results suggest potential antioxidant benefits, though higher doses and longer durations may be needed for clearer effects.
population_specificity: Young girls with both PMS and dysmenorrhea (n=80).
study_duration: 7 days pre- until 3 days post-menstrual bleeding for 3 successive cycles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of piperine on muscle force production, its reversibility, and potential mechanisms, including Ca2+ sensitivity.
results_summary: Piperine increased low-frequency force in both slow- and fast-twitch muscle, was reversible, and partially recovered force in fatigued muscle. The primary mechanism was an increase in Ca2+ sensitivity without affecting intracellular Ca2+ levels.
population_specificity: Rats and mice (isolated muscles and single fibres)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the bioavailability of a natural turmeric extract (WDTE60N) with a reference product containing curcuminoids and piperine (CPC).
results_summary: The test formulation WDTE60N demonstrated improved relative absorption and equivalent exposure at a 10-fold-lower dose of actives compared to the reference CPC, which contained piperine. Piperine was used in the reference product to enhance bioavailability, but the study did not isolate its individual effects.
population_specificity: Sixteen healthy adult male subjects.
effective_dosage: Reference product CPC contained 500 mg curcuminoids and 5 mg piperine, administered 3 times daily (total 15 mg piperine/day).
study_duration: Single-day dosing with blood sampling over 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the molecular mechanism of a 308-nm excimer laser combined with piperine in regulating melanocyte proliferation, migration, and melanin production for vitiligo treatment.
results_summary: The combination of the 308-nm excimer laser and piperine enhanced melanocyte proliferation, migration, and melanin production, upregulated miR-328, and inhibited SFRP1, activating the Wnt/β-catenin pathway. Restraint of miR-328 reversed these effects.
population_specificity: Epidermal melanocytes in vitro

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the leishmanicidal activity and safety of piperine (PIP) as a potential topical treatment for cutaneous leishmaniasis caused by L. braziliensis.
results_summary: Piperine showed high in vitro leishmanicidal activity at 8 mM and no cytotoxicity for U937 macrophages. In vivo, topical PIP treatment cured 67% of infected hamsters, demonstrating moderate efficacy compared to quercetin (100%) and curcumin (83%).
population_specificity: Golden hamsters infected with stationary-phase L. braziliensis promastigotes.
effective_dosage: Not specified (in vitro: 8 mM; in vivo: concentration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-prostate cancer (PCa) effects of piperine, particularly its ability to inhibit AKT1 activity, DNA damage, and colony formation in PC3 cells compared to SDF.
results_summary: Piperine significantly inhibited colony formation and caused DNA damage in PC3 cells, demonstrating stronger effects than SDF. Molecular dynamics simulations indicated stable binding of piperine to AKT1, suggesting potential for inhibiting PCa cell proliferation.
population_specificity: Human prostate cancer cell line PC3 (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biological activity of Piperine-loaded chitosan lipid nanoparticles (PP-CLNPs) alone or combined with Metformin for managing cognitive deficits in diabetic rats.
results_summary: PP-CLNPs showed high entrapment efficiency, enhanced in vitro release, and improved cognitive function while reducing oxidative stress in diabetic rats. Piperine also acted as a bio-enhancer, increasing Metformin's potency in protecting brain tissue from neuroinflammation and memory deterioration.
population_specificity: Diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining Piperine (PIP) with Sorafenib (SORA) in PLGA nanoparticles could improve efficacy outcomes in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) treatment.
results_summary: The study found that PIP and SORA co-loaded into PLGA nanoparticles exhibited sustained drug release, high encapsulation efficiency, and superior cytotoxicity against HepG2 cells compared to SORA monotherapy. The formulation showed potential as an effective strategy for HCC treatment.
population_specificity: In vitro study using HepG2 hepatocellular carcinoma cells.
effective_dosage: Not specified (drugs co-loaded into nanoparticles with 0.5% PVA).
interactions: Improved pharmacokinetic profiles of Sorafenib when combined with Piperine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of Piperine in NASH progression and identify its potential mechanisms, particularly focusing on hepatocyte pyroptosis and NF-κB inhibition.
results_summary: Piperine alleviated liver steatosis, inflammation, hepatocyte injury, and fibrosis in mice fed with MCD diets. It also reduced pyroptosis markers (NLRP3, ASC, caspase-1 p20, GSDMD), IL-1β, and LDH release, with NF-κB activation suppression playing a key role.
population_specificity: Mice with methionine- and choline-deficient (MCD) diet-induced NASH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Piperine (PIP) could protect against cyclophosphamide (CP)-induced testicular toxicity in mice by examining its antioxidant, antiapoptotic, and anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: PIP treatment reduced CP-induced testicular toxicity, improving sperm count, motility, and viability, while also mitigating oxidative stress, apoptosis, and histopathological damage. The protective effects were dose-dependent, with higher doses (10 mg/kg) showing more pronounced benefits.
population_specificity: Adult male BALB/c mice (30-35 g)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of piperine on hyperuricemic nephropathy (HN) in mice and renal tubular epithelial cells, focusing on its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and uric acid-lowering properties.
results_summary: Piperine significantly reduced serum uric acid levels, improved kidney function in HN mice, and alleviated uric acid-induced damage in renal cells. It also inhibited transporter expression and activity, regulating the AKT/mTOR pathway both in vivo and in vitro.
population_specificity: Adenine and potassium oxonate-induced HN mice and uric acid-injured renal tubular epithelial cells (mRTECs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of piperine on gut microbiota composition and diversity in the context of arsenic exposure using a mouse model.
results_summary: The study found shifts in microbial composition and abundance among intervention groups, suggesting piperine may influence gut microbiota diversity when co-administered with arsenic. However, specific taxa contributing to these changes were not detailed.
population_specificity: Mouse model (cecal samples from intervention groups: arsenic exposure, arsenic + piperine, piperine alone, and control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of piperine in hepatic ischemia/reperfusion injury (HIRI) and its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Piperine pretreatment improved liver function, reduced oxidative stress, decreased inflammatory cell infiltration, and attenuated TNF-α and IL-6 production by inhibiting the TLR4/IRAK1/NF-κB signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to hepatic ischemia-reperfusion injury.
study_duration: Pretreatment before surgery, with evaluation after 24 hours of ischemia-reperfusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and RCM features of re-pigmentation in localized vitiligo using a combination of NB-UVB and piperine-based topical treatment.
results_summary: The study found that the combined treatment led to macules being "slightly less noticeable" with 25-50% re-pigmentation, along with significant improvements in irregular honeycomb patterns, non-pigmented papillae, dendritic cells, and blood vessels.
population_specificity: Eight patients with localized vitiligo enrolled at a single center.
effective_dosage: Topical treatment applied twice daily + NB-UVB twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of piperine on blood glucose and insulin levels by modulating hepatic HNF-1α and SREBP-1c expression in T2DM rats and human Chang liver cells, comparing it to metformin.
results_summary: Piperine significantly reduced blood glucose and insulin levels in T2DM rats, upregulated HNF-1α mRNA, and downregulated SREBP-1c mRNA, with effects comparable to metformin. In vitro studies confirmed similar gene expression changes in Chang liver cells.
population_specificity: Adult male albino rats with HFD and sucrose-induced T2DM, and human Chang liver cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of piperine, including its bioactive effects, physiological benefits, and role in enhancing drug bioavailability.
results_summary: The study found that piperine exhibits multiple bioactive effects, including antibacterial, immunomodulatory, hepatoprotective, antioxidant, antimetastatic, and anticancer properties. Clinical trials highlighted its exceptional antioxidant, anticancer, and drug availability-enhancing capabilities, as well as immunomodulatory potential.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human health context).
interactions: Enhances bioavailability of other therapeutic medications, including chemotherapy drugs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antifungal and antibiofilm activity of piperine against Candida albicans, both alone and in combination with conventional antifungals.
results_summary: Piperine demonstrated antibiofilm activity with MBIC and MBEC ranging from 64 to 1024 μg/mL and 256 to 2048 μg/mL, respectively. It showed synergistic effects when combined with antifungals, particularly azoles, outperforming curcumin in synergy.
population_specificity: Multiresistant clinical isolates of Candida albicans.
interactions: Synergistic effects noted with azoles and polyenes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of piperine consumption on patients with NAFLD and early cirrhosis compared to placebo over 12 weeks.
results_summary: Piperine at 5 mg daily significantly reduced hepatic enzymes, glucose levels, and dyslipidemia, and improved HOMA levels and insulin resistance in NAFLD patients compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Patients with NAFLD and early-stage cirrhosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether colon-targeted piperine-glycyrrhizic acid nanocrystals (ES100-PIP/GA NCs) could effectively treat ulcerative colitis by modulating macrophage activity and reducing inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that ES100-PIP/GA NCs exhibited high drug loading and colon-specific release, effectively downregulated pro-inflammatory factors (IL-1β, IL-17A), upregulated anti-inflammatory factors (TGF-β1), repaired the intestinal mucosal barrier, and significantly inhibited colitis in a murine model. The nanocrystals also enhanced M2 macrophages and inhibited M1 macrophages through mTOR and HIF-1α regulation.
population_specificity: Murine model (mice with dextran sodium sulfate-induced acute colitis) and in vitro studies using RAW 264.7 and Caco-2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piperine (PIP) could improve the quality of porcine oocytes during in vitro maturation by reducing oxidative stress and enhancing subsequent embryo development.
results_summary: The study found that 200 μM PIP significantly improved blastocyst formation, reduced apoptosis, decreased reactive oxygen species, increased glutathione levels, and enhanced antioxidant and developmental gene expression in porcine oocytes. These benefits also translated to improved embryo development following somatic cell nuclear transfer.
population_specificity: Porcine oocytes
study_duration: Duration of in vitro maturation (exact time not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects of piperine on the HL-60 cell line, focusing on its role in apoptosis and modulation of microRNAs and gene expression in AML.
results_summary: Piperine increased HL-60 cell viability and significantly upregulated miR-181a and c-Kit expression while also increasing BAX expression, suggesting potential anticancer effects. However, its impact on cell viability was mixed compared to other compounds tested.
population_specificity: HL-60 cell line (in vitro) and 150 newly diagnosed AML patients (for miR analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Piperine's inhibitory mechanism on P-glycoprotein (P-gp) and its ability to enhance the sensitivity of paclitaxel (PTX) in treating triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), as well as the safety and efficacy of albumin nanoparticles co-encapsulating PTX and PIP (PP@AN).
results_summary: Piperine enhanced intracellular PTX accumulation, increased cell sensitivity to PTX, and inhibited P-gp by competing with PTX binding, downregulating MDR1 gene and P-gp expression. PP@AN improved drug accumulation, downregulated P-gp in tumors, and reduced toxicity while enhancing antitumor effects in vivo.
population_specificity: Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) models (in vitro and in vivo).
effective_dosage: Optimal ratio PTX:PIP = 1:2 (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-Candida activity of piperine, its mechanisms of action, and its impact on virulence factors in Candida albicans.
results_summary: Piperine suppressed hyphal transition, hindered biofilm formation, disrupted cell membrane permeability and mitochondrial membrane potential, and induced reactive oxygen species accumulation in C. albicans. It also showed synergy with fluconazole against fluconazole-sensitive strains and demonstrated low cytotoxicity at low concentrations.
population_specificity: Fluconazole-sensitive and fluconazole-resistant Candida albicans strains.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a curcumin-piperine combination on inflammatory markers, lipid profiles, and other health indicators in patients recovering from ischemic stroke.
results_summary: The curcumin-piperine combination significantly reduced hs-CRP, total cholesterol, triglycerides, CIMT, weight, waist circumference, and blood pressure while increasing total antioxidant capacity. Pain scores increased less in the intervention group compared to placebo, but no significant changes were observed in fibrinogen, LDL, HDL, or quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with ischemic stroke in the rehabilitation stage (mean age 59.80 ± 4.25 years).
effective_dosage: 500 mg curcumin + 5 mg piperine per tablet (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the formulation and effectiveness of PPN-encapsulated PCL nanoparticles (PPN-PCL-NPs) for improving the therapeutic efficacy of Piperine in breast cancer treatment.
results_summary: The optimized PPN-PCL-NPs demonstrated stable pharmaceutical attributes, sustained release over 48 hours, and significantly enhanced cytotoxic effects against MCF-7 breast cancer cells compared to native Piperine.
population_specificity: In vitro study using MCF-7 breast cancer cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antiangiogenic efficacy of Piperine (PPR) against VEGF-A and VEGFR-2 in Glioblastoma (GBM) and elucidate its mechanism of action.
results_summary: Piperine demonstrated dose-dependent inhibition of U87-induced neoangiogenesis, reducing VEGF-A and VEGFR-2 transcript expression at noncytotoxic concentrations (≤11 µM), with superior effectiveness compared to nimbolide and trans-chalcone.
population_specificity: U87 (Uppsala 87 Malignant Glioma) cell lines and chick chorioallantoic membrane (CAM) models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore piperine's potential role in cancer chemoprevention and its ability to enhance conventional cancer treatments.
results_summary: The study found that piperine exhibits antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and immunomodulatory effects, inhibiting molecular events and signaling pathways linked to cancer development. It also enhances the effectiveness of treatments like UV-phototherapy and TRAIL-based therapy.
population_specificity: Not specified (general cancer-related mechanisms discussed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate piperine-induced apoptosis and autophagy in HSC-3 human oral cancer cells and its effects on tumor growth in vivo.
results_summary: Piperine reduced HSC-3 cell viability, induced apoptosis and autophagy, and inhibited the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway, demonstrating antitumor effects in vivo.
population_specificity: HSC-3 human oral cancer cells and in vivo tumor models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if piperine could modulate the non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ) pathway to overcome radioresistance in breast cancer cells.
results_summary: Piperine enhanced radiation-induced cell death by altering estrogen receptor α/β ratios, reducing DNA-PK repair complex expression, and increasing DNA damage, leading to cell cycle arrest and apoptosis. It also shared pharmacophore features with known estrogen agonists/antagonists.
population_specificity: Estrogen receptor-positive/negative breast cancer cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antitumour efficacy of a liposomal co-delivery system (iRGD-LP-CUR-PIP) containing curcumin and piperine for lung cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found that iRGD-LP-CUR-PIP enhanced tumour targeting, cellular uptake, and antitumour activity in vitro and in vivo, showing significant tumour volume reduction and synergistic effects between curcumin and piperine.
population_specificity: Lung cancer models (in vitro and in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the antibacterial and immunomodulatory properties of piperine (PPN) through in vitro, in vivo, and in silico studies.
results_summary: The study identified six key aspects of PPN activity, including antibacterial effects, efflux pump inhibition, biofilm disruption, and immune modulation, with most research focusing on Mycobacterium spp. and Staphylococcus aureus. PPN showed potential as an adjuvant in treating bacterial infections, though further exploration of its mechanisms is needed.
population_specificity: Primarily Mycobacterium spp. and Staphylococcus aureus in cell lineages and in vivo models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effect of piperine on sepsis-associated encephalopathy (SAE) in C57BL/6 mice subjected to cecum ligation and perforation surgery (CLP).
results_summary: Piperine treatment reduced inflammatory markers (IL-6, TBARS), decreased neuronal degeneration, and improved memory in septic mice. It also increased catalase and BDNF levels, demonstrating neuroprotective effects.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 male mice subjected to CLP surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Piperine's potential biochemical targets, anti-leishmanial mechanisms, and immunomodulatory roles, particularly in combination with meglumine antimoniate.
results_summary: Piperine showed binding affinity to IL-12P40 and IFN-γ, enhanced anti-leishmanial effects when combined with meglumine antimoniate, and upregulated Th1-related cytokines while downregulating Th2-related cytokines in treated macrophages.
population_specificity: Leishmania major promastigotes, amastigotes, and murine macrophages.
effective_dosage: IC50 values of 43.22 μg/mL (promastigotes) and 19.41 μg/mL (amastigotes) for the combination therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidepressant-like activity of nanopiperine in LPS-induced depression in mice and compare its effects to pure piperine.
results_summary: Nanopiperine reversed LPS-induced depression in mice, improved hippocampal progenitor cell proliferation, increased BDNF levels, and elevated neurotransmitter levels. It also showed better oral bioavailability and stability compared to pure piperine.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to LPS-induced stress.
effective_dosage: 5 and 10 mg/kg body weight for 14 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cytotoxic, apoptotic, and anti-cancer effects of piperine (Pip) alone and in combination with sodium pentaborate pentahydrate (NaB) and curcumin (Cur) on hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cell lines.
results_summary: Piperine alone showed no significant toxic effect on HCC cell lines (HepG2 and Hep3B), but in combination with NaB and Cur, it demonstrated synergistic anti-cancer activity, enhancing cytotoxicity, apoptosis, and cell cycle disruption. Transcriptome analysis confirmed the combined treatment's anti-cancer effects.
population_specificity: In vitro study using two HCC cell lines (HepG2 and Hep3B).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine whether piperine, as a bioenhancer, could improve the bioavailability and bioefficacy of resveratrol when combined with exercise training to increase skeletal muscle mitochondrial capacity.
results_summary: The study found that resveratrol plus piperine supplementation significantly increased mitochondrial capacity (40% improvement) compared to placebo (10% improvement) when combined with low-intensity exercise training. No changes were observed in the untrained arm for either group.
population_specificity: Healthy young adults (n=16)
effective_dosage: 10 mg of piperine daily (combined with 500 mg resveratrol)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of NSO (250 mg) with 2.5 mg piperine as a supplement for managing allergic rhinitis symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that NSO with piperine significantly reduced Total Nasal Symptom Score and Total Ocular Symptoms Score compared to placebo, with no clinically significant adverse effects. Serum Immunoglobulin E levels decreased in the NSO group but were not significantly different from placebo.
population_specificity: 65 participants aged 18-60 years with allergic rhinitis symptoms.
effective_dosage: 2.5 mg piperine (BioPerine) twice daily with NSO (250 mg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a curcuminoid-piperine combination in improving oxidative stress and inflammation in patients with metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: The curcuminoid-piperine combination significantly improved serum SOD activities and reduced MDA and CRP concentrations compared to placebo, demonstrating strong antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects. The meta-analysis confirmed a significant reduction in CRP levels with curcuminoid therapy.
population_specificity: 117 subjects with metabolic syndrome (MetS) according to NCEP-ATPIII criteria.
effective_dosage: 10 mg/day of piperine co-supplemented with 1 g/day of curcuminoids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Piracetam could mitigate Valproic acid-induced placental toxicity and abnormal fetal development in rats by targeting angiogenesis and oxidative stress.
results_summary: Piracetam improved placental histopathology, restored fetal growth metrics, reduced malformations, and enhanced placental angiogenesis while reducing oxidative stress via the VEGF/eNOS/TGF-β pathway.
population_specificity: Pregnant rats exposed to Valproic acid.
study_duration: From the 6th to 15th day of gestation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether co-supplementation of piperine with resveratrol enhances resveratrol's bioavailability and efficacy regarding cognitive function and cerebral blood flow.
results_summary: Piperine co-supplementation with resveratrol significantly increased cerebral blood flow during cognitive tasks compared to placebo or resveratrol alone, but did not affect cognitive performance, mood, or blood pressure. Plasma concentrations of resveratrol and its metabolites remained unchanged, suggesting enhanced bioefficacy without altered bioavailability.
population_specificity: 23 healthy, young adults
effective_dosage: 20 mg piperine co-administered with 250 mg trans-resveratrol
study_duration: Single administration with at least a week between treatments

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective potential of a nanoemulsion containing Piracetam and Shatavarin IV for treating Alzheimer's disease, focusing on molecular docking, formulation optimization, and characterization.
results_summary: The study found that the nanoemulsion exhibited strong binding affinities with AD-related targets, synergistic effects between Piracetam and Shatavarin IV, enhanced drug release and permeability, and improved antioxidant activity compared to the pure extract.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and ex vivo studies, no human participants mentioned).
effective_dosage: 1:1 ratio of Piracetam and Shatavarin IV (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of CPCGI against piracetam in improving cognitive and functional outcomes in mild to moderate TBI patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding piracetam's effects, as the study is described as ongoing or not yet concluded.
population_specificity: Adult patients with mild to moderate traumatic brain injury (TBI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the efficacy and safety of piracetam compared to placebo or other medications in children with breath-holding spells (BHS).
results_summary: Piracetam significantly increased favorable responses and reduced the frequency of BHS compared to placebo, with comparable adverse effects between groups. Its efficacy was further enhanced by co-administration of docosahexaenoic acid.
population_specificity: Children with breath-holding spells (BHS).
study_duration: Outcomes were assessed at 1, 2, and 3 months post-randomization.
interactions: Co-administration with oral docosahexaenoic acid improved efficacy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of piracetam on astrocyte function in rats genetically prone to audiogenic seizures and compare its action in normal rats.
results_summary: Piracetam normalized the expression of most astrocyte markers in epileptic rats and enhanced specific markers in normal rats, suggesting its antiepileptic effects may involve astroglia modulation. The study also identified a novel pattern of astrocyte heterogeneity altered in epileptic rats but corrected by piracetam.
population_specificity: Krushinsky-Molodkina (KM) rats genetically prone to audiogenic seizures and normal Wistar rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanism of piracetam for treating spinal cord injury in rats, focusing on the MAPK pathway.
results_summary: Piracetam improved motor function recovery, reduced spinal cord lesion area, regulated AQP4 expression to reduce edema, and decreased inflammatory response by modulating the MAPK pathway. The treatment group showed better BBB scores, reduced necrosis, and lower inflammatory markers compared to the injury group.
population_specificity: 6-week-old female SD rats with induced spinal cord injury.
effective_dosage: 5 ml·kg⁻¹ via tail vein injection, once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore Piracetam's protective effects against cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity and elucidate its underlying molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: Piracetam improved renal function markers, reduced histological damage, exhibited antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects, and inhibited apoptotic pathways in cisplatin-exposed subjects.
population_specificity: Animal model (specific species not mentioned in the abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of piracetam on memory function in adults with cognitive impairment compared to a placebo.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 18 studies found no clinically significant difference in memory enhancement between piracetam and placebo groups (SMD 0.75; 95% CI [-0.19; 1.69]; p=0.12). The study concluded that piracetam's impact on memory remains inconclusive.
population_specificity: Adults with impaired cognitive function

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the effect of Piracetam on oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction in a cellular model of vascular dementia (VaD).
results_summary: Piracetam enhanced cell growth, inhibited oxidative stress, and improved mitochondrial function in OGD-stimulated SH-SY5Y cells by inhibiting the PI3K/Akt/mTOR pathway. The findings suggest Piracetam has potential as a treatment for VaD.
population_specificity: In vitro cellular model (OGD-stimulated SH-SY5Y cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of piracetam and iron on heart rate variability (HRV) and treatment effectiveness in children with breath-holding spells.
results_summary: Piracetam treatment showed statistically significant improvements in HRV parameters and a significant reduction in the number of breath-holding attacks, indicating positive efficacy.
population_specificity: Children aged six months to five years with breath-holding spells (cyanotic or pale types).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective potential of piracetam against brain injury and inflammation induced by etoposide in a rodent model.
results_summary: Piracetam co-treatment counteracted etoposide-induced brain injury and altered serum biomarker levels, suggesting a protective effect against inflammation and brain toxicity.
population_specificity: Female albino rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Piracetam could mitigate neurological complications, oxidative stress, and mitochondrial dysfunction in a mouse model of hepatic encephalopathy induced by thioacetamide.
results_summary: Piracetam significantly improved locomotor activity, reduced oxidative stress biomarkers, decreased inflammatory cytokines, and enhanced mitochondrial function in hyperammonemic mice. The study suggests Piracetam has neuroprotective potential for managing hepatic encephalopathy.
population_specificity: Mice with thioacetamide-induced hepatic encephalopathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy of intravenous piracetam combined with external ventricular drain and intraventricular urokinase injection in treating intraventricular hemorrhage.
results_summary: The experimental group receiving piracetam showed shorter hematoma elimination time, drainage tube removal time, and hospitalization time, along with improved GCS scores, neurological function recovery, and lower surgical complication rates compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 60 patients with intraventricular hemorrhage at Baoding First Central Hospital, China.
study_duration: Treatment duration not explicitly stated, but outcomes were measured within one month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a combination of piracetam and diethylstilbestrol could prevent grand-mal seizures in rats and elucidate the underlying mechanism involving the PI3K/Akt/mTOR pathway.
results_summary: The low-dose combination of piracetam (10 mg/kg) and diethylstilbestrol (10 mg/kg) showed synergistic anti-seizure and neuroprotective effects, reducing hippocampal mTOR and proinflammatory cytokines, and improving cell viability in HEK-293 cells exposed to PTZ.
population_specificity: Rats (animal study)
effective_dosage: Piracetam 10 mg/kg and 20 mg/kg, diethylstilbestrol 10 mg/kg and 20 mg/kg

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Piracetam could ameliorate Cyclophosphamide-induced hepatotoxicity in rats by modulating apoptotic, necroptotic, and pyroptotic pathways.
results_summary: Piracetam significantly improved liver function, reduced markers of apoptosis and inflammation, and corrected histopathological abnormalities caused by Cyclophosphamide. It also shifted the Bax/Bcl-2 ratio toward anti-apoptosis and reduced caspase-3, TNF-α, and COX-2 expression.
population_specificity: Rats (40, divided into four groups)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Piracetam, alone and in combination with Citicoline, on hypoxic-ischemic brain damage in rabbit neonates.
results_summary: Piracetam reduced neuronal destruction rates (37.5% vs. 45% in the hypoxic-ischemic control group), but its effect was less pronounced than Citicoline alone. The combination of Piracetam and Citicoline showed no superior effect compared to Citicoline alone.
population_specificity: Rabbit neonates with induced hypoxic-ischemic brain damage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Piracetam and Levetiracetam on reducing the severity and frequency of breath-holding spells (BHS) in children.
results_summary: Piracetam significantly reduced the frequency of BHS but had no significant effect on loss of consciousness. It showed a 77.1% partial or complete response rate, which was lower but not significantly different from Levetiracetam's 88.9%.
population_specificity: Children aged 6 months to 6 years with severe breath-holding spells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective effect of co-administering piracetam and caffeine on scopolamine-induced amnesia in rats.
results_summary: Pre-treatment with caffeine and piracetam decreased scopolamine-induced cognitive damage and amnesia, demonstrating improved learning tendency. The mechanism requires further investigation, but the combination shows potential as a novel therapeutic strategy for combating amnesia.
population_specificity: Rats with scopolamine-induced amnesia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the synergistic effects of piracetam in combination with vinpocetine and cinnarizine for neuroprotective and nootropic benefits.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of vinpocetine and piracetam had a higher synergism score (54) compared to piracetam and cinnarizine (25), suggesting better combined efficacy.
population_specificity: Model organisms (mice, rats) and neuronal cultures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if systemic piracetam treatment could protect against ischemia-reperfusion injury in musculocutaneous flaps as a simpler alternative to ischemic preconditioning.
results_summary: Piracetam significantly reduced myeloperoxidase activity and acute inflammatory cell response, similar to preconditioning, and increased nitric oxide levels, but did not significantly affect vascular proliferation.
population_specificity: Rats with latissimus dorsi musculocutaneous flaps.
effective_dosage: Systemic piracetam administered 30 minutes before and 6 days after reperfusion (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining piracetam with nimodipine improves cognitive function and quality of life in patients with vascular dementia after cerebral infarction.
results_summary: The study found that piracetam combined with nimodipine significantly improved cognitive function (measured by ADL, MoCA, ADAS-Cog, and MMSE scores) and quality of life compared to nimodipine alone, with effects becoming more pronounced after 3 months and half a year of treatment.
population_specificity: 98 patients with vascular dementia after cerebral infarction.
study_duration: At least half a year (6 months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the muscle-protective effects of piracetam combined with L-carnitine against simvastatin-induced muscle injury and exercise-related myopathic symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that the test group (piracetam + L-carnitine) had lower incidence of pain/discomfort and reduced serum levels of muscle injury markers (AST, ALT, LDH) compared to the control group, suggesting a protective effect against simvastatin-induced myalgia. The formulation was also reported as safe and well-tolerated.
population_specificity: Healthy male subjects (42 in occasion 1, 19 in occasion 2).
effective_dosage: 80 mg/mL piracetam + 100 mg/mL L-carnitine, 10 mL oral solution once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of piracetam, alone and in combination with risperidone, in reversing PTSD-like behavioral and physiological changes in rats.
results_summary: Piracetam was effective alone and showed a potentiating effect in combination with risperidone, reversing extinction deficits, behavioral alterations, and restoring neurotransmitter levels, BDNF, inflammatory markers, and oxidative stress markers in the hippocampus and cortex. The combination also normalized plasma corticosterone and nitrite levels.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats exposed to a single prolonged stress model (SPS) to induce PTSD-like behaviors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of piracetam, theophylline, and iron treatments in reducing the frequency of breath-holding spells (BHS) in children.
results_summary: Piracetam showed minimal effectiveness, with only an 8.8% reduction in the frequency of BHS attacks per month, significantly lower than theophylline (82.9%) and iron (58.8%). Parental satisfaction was notably low for piracetam compared to theophylline.
population_specificity: 146 children (75 girls, 71 boys) with simple breath-holding spells, predominantly cyanotic (83.6%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the neuroprotective effects of piracetam, alone and in combination with zafirlukast, on L-methionine-induced vascular dementia in rats.
results_summary: Piracetam improved neurochemical, behavioral, and histological alterations in rats with L-methionine-induced vascular dementia, with comparable efficacy to zafirlukast and the combination therapy.
population_specificity: Male Wistar albino rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of a novel hybrid nanosystem containing piracetam and vinpocetine in reversing scopolamine-induced memory impairment.
results_summary: The nanoformulations (transethosomal, microemulsion, and nanocomposite) effectively reversed scopolamine-induced memory deficits, reduced acetylcholinesterase activity and lipid peroxidation, and demonstrated anti-inflammatory and antiapoptotic effects, with the nanocomposite formulation showing superior performance.
population_specificity: Sheep nasal mucosa (preclinical model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the associations between piracetam use and NIHSS score changes in ischemic stroke patients, identifying clinical characteristics that influence its effectiveness.
results_summary: The study found that piracetam was associated with NIHSS score improvement in specific subgroups, including patients aged ≥75, males, normal/obese weight individuals, ex-smokers, and those with hypertension or dyslipidemia but without diabetes or atrial fibrillation.
population_specificity: Ischemic stroke patients from a Taiwanese hospital (excluding those with thrombolytic treatment, incomplete NIHSS scores, or transient ischemic stroke).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of oral piracetam versus oral betahistine in managing peripheral vertigo in outpatients.
results_summary: Piracetam showed comparable efficacy to betahistine in managing peripheral vertigo, with similar recurrence rates and physician revisit rates. However, piracetam had a higher incidence of adverse events (24% vs. 12%), though the difference was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Outpatients presenting to emergency departments with peripheral vertigo (mean age 54.72 ± 14.09 years, 62% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze piracetam's inhibitory effect on AGE formation in glycated albumin and its influence on the interaction between gliclazide and glycated albumin.
results_summary: Piracetam strongly inhibited AGE formation in glycated albumin but increased the binding strength of gliclazide to glycated albumin, potentially weakening gliclazide's therapeutic effect. The study suggests caution when combining piracetam and gliclazide in treatment.
population_specificity: In vitro study using human serum albumin (HSA) and glycated albumin (gHSAFRC).
interactions: Interaction with gliclazide noted, potentially weakening its therapeutic effect.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the relative stability of piracetam polymorphs (P1, P2, P3) under varying temperatures using ssNMR spectroscopy and DFT calculations.
results_summary: The study found that DFT calculations could predict the temperature-dependent stability order of piracetam polymorphs and supported polymorphic phase transition analysis in pure and commercial formulations.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on polymorphic forms of piracetam, not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of the caspase-independent pathway in piracetam-mediated neuroprotection against LPS-induced oxidative stress and inflammation.
results_summary: Piracetam treatment significantly protected against LPS-induced oxidative stress, inflammation, and mitochondrial dysfunction, while also inhibiting caspase-independent apoptotic pathways and restoring neuronal integrity.
population_specificity: Rat brain (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacological effects of piracetam on binge eating disorder (BED) in female rats, focusing on its impact on binge eating behavior, cognitive deficits, and neurotransmitter levels.
results_summary: Piracetam significantly reduced binge eating behavior and associated weight gain, regulated neurotransmitter levels, and alleviated anxiety and cognitive deficits in BED rats. It did not affect normal feeding behavior in the fast-refed model and showed brain region-specific effects on vascular endothelial growth factor expression.
population_specificity: Female rats with induced binge eating disorder (BED).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pre-treatment with piracetam could protect cells from apoptosis induced by sonoporation and explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Piracetam pre-treatment protected cells from sonoporation-associated apoptosis by reducing reactive oxygen species, preserving mitochondrial membrane potential, inhibiting caspase-3/7 activity, and enhancing ATP production, thereby improving gene transfection without compromising cell viability.
population_specificity: In vitro cell study (specific cell type not mentioned in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Piracetam's role in neuroprotection by examining its effects on mitochondrion-specific factors of the caspase-independent pathway, anti-inflammatory properties, and antioxidative effects.
results_summary: Piracetam attenuated LPS-induced cytotoxicity, mitochondrial dysfunction, reactive oxygen species generation, and proinflammatory cytokine expression. It also reduced oxidative DNA fragmentation and PARP-1 up-regulation, demonstrating neuroprotective, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidative properties.
population_specificity: Neuronal N2A cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Piracetam could protect against ethanol-induced cognitive deficits and neuronal damage by investigating its effects on synaptic plasticity, apoptosis, and autophagy pathways.
results_summary: Piracetam improved long-term potentiation, reduced neuronal apoptosis, and modulated autophagy and mTOR/Akt pathways, demonstrating protective effects against ethanol-induced cognitive deficits in juvenile rats.
population_specificity: Juvenile rats exposed to ethanol

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate piracetam's effects on LPS-induced neuroinflammation and resulting cognitive and behavioral changes.
results_summary: Piracetam attenuated LPS-induced anxiety and spatial memory impairment, improved mitochondrial function, reduced oxidative stress, and demonstrated anti-neuroinflammatory effects by lowering IL-6 levels and promoting Aβ efflux from the hippocampus to blood.
population_specificity: Animal model (rats) with LPS-induced neuroinflammation.
effective_dosage: 50, 100, and 200 mg/kg i.p., administered 30 min before LPS infusion and continued for 9 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of piracetam in reducing the incidence of painful sickle cell disease crises.
results_summary: The study found insufficient reliable evidence to support piracetam's routine use for preventing painful sickle cell crises, with mixed and incomplete data on pain reduction and severity. No significant adverse effects were reported, except for one case of dizziness.
population_specificity: People of all ages and both sexes with sickle cell disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antioxidant properties and protective effects of piracetam on testicular tissue in a rat model of testicular torsion/detorsion.
results_summary: Piracetam (200 mg/kg) significantly reduced oxidative stress (TOS values) compared to the torsion/detorsion group, demonstrating protective effects on testicular tissue. However, its efficacy relative to other treatments (udenafil, dexmedetomidine) was not directly compared in the abstract.
population_specificity: Wistar albino rats (n=10 in piracetam group)
study_duration: Single dose after 60 minutes of testicular torsion

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review literature on piracetam's use as a heroin adulterant, explore its potential mechanisms, and assess whether it could aid in reducing heroin withdrawal symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that piracetam may protect neurons from heroin-induced apoptosis, potentially due to restored beta-endorphin levels and neuroprotective effects. It also suggested piracetam's adulteration in heroin might enhance desirable effects while reducing hangover.
population_specificity: Heroin users (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piracetam improves language rehabilitation in post-stroke patients through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Piracetam showed no significant improvement in overall aphasia severity but demonstrated a pronounced benefit in written language ability. Its effects were short-term, with declining efficacy over time.
population_specificity: Post-stroke patients without pre-existing cognitive disorders such as dementia or mood disturbances.
effective_dosage: Consistent dose (specific amount not stated), but frequency and therapy duration varied.
study_duration: Varied across studies (not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of systemic and topical administration of piracetam on full-thickness skin burn wound healing in rabbits.
results_summary: Both systemic (piracetam-IV) and topical (piracetam-C) administration of piracetam significantly enhanced full-thickness burn wound healing, with piracetam-C being more effective and practical. Histopathological analysis showed that wounds treated with piracetam-C resembled those of the control group more closely than other treatments.
population_specificity: New Zealand male rabbits with induced full-thickness skin burns.
study_duration: 14 days of administration, with outcomes assessed at 21 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of betahistine plus piracetam dual therapy versus betahistine monotherapy in patients with peripheral vestibular vertigo.
results_summary: The study found that betahistine plus piracetam showed statistically significant improvements in DHI functional scores and a higher percentage of patients with no impairment compared to betahistine alone. Adverse events were low and similar in both groups, with no discontinuations due to drug-related effects.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral vestibular vertigo (n=2272, with 114 receiving dual therapy and 567 receiving monotherapy in the analyzed subset).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piracetam enhances heroin's reward properties and its effects on neuronal apoptosis and β-endorphin levels in the brain.
results_summary: Piracetam significantly enhanced heroin-induced conditioned place preference (CPP) but did not induce CPP on its own. It also reduced neuronal apoptosis and normalized β-endorphin levels in specific brain regions compared to heroin alone.
population_specificity: Heroin-treated rats (animal study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the neuroprotective effects of piracetam against rotenone-induced oxidative stress in rat brain models.
results_summary: Pretreatment with piracetam significantly attenuated rotenone-induced oxidative stress in a region-specific manner, enhancing antioxidant capacity in brain cells. Co-treatment with piracetam did not show significant protection in ex vivo studies.
population_specificity: Rats (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mitochondrion-specific endonuclease G is involved in piracetam's protective mechanisms against LPS-induced damage in astrocytes.
results_summary: Piracetam attenuated LPS-induced decreases in cell viability, mitochondrial activity, oxidative stress, chromatin condensation, and DNA fragmentation. It also inhibited LPS-induced translocation of endonuclease G to the nucleus, suggesting a protective role.
population_specificity: Astrocyte glial cells (in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic efficacy of piracetam and dimenhydrinate in reducing vertigo symptoms in emergency department patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between piracetam and dimenhydrinate in reducing vertigo intensity, with similar rescue medication needs and only one reported adverse reaction.
population_specificity: Healthy adult patients presenting to the emergency department with undifferentiated vertigo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the nootropic activity of piracetam alone and in combination with duloxetine in mice.
results_summary: Piracetam alone showed significant improvements in memory tasks (reduced transfer latency in EPM and increased time in target quadrant in MWM), but the combination with duloxetine did not produce statistically significant nootropic effects and failed to increase brain monoamine levels except for norepinephrine in the hippocampus.
population_specificity: Male Swiss Albino mice
interactions: Combination with duloxetine showed no cognitive benefits and limited monoamine level increases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of piracetam on peripheral neuropathic pain in rats.
results_summary: Piracetam at 200 mg/kg significantly reduced neuropathic pain symptoms (thermal hyperalgesia and cold allodynia), while lower doses (50 and 100 mg/kg) showed limited or no effect.
population_specificity: Rats with chronic constriction injury-induced neuropathic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanism by which piracetam reduces neuronal damage induced by oxygen and glucose deprivation (OGD) in rat primary cortical cells.
results_summary: Piracetam significantly reduced neuronal damage, oxidative stress, and excitatory amino acid release while enhancing antioxidant enzyme activity and lowering P53/Bax protein expression in OGD-exposed cortical cells.
population_specificity: Rat primary cortical cells subjected to oxygen and glucose deprivation (OGD).
effective_dosage: Added to cultured cells 12 hours before OGD (specific dosage not mentioned).
study_duration: 4 hours of OGD exposure after 12-hour pre-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effect of piracetam on cognitive performance in patients undergoing coronary bypass surgery.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that piracetam significantly improved short-term cognitive performance in patients, as evidenced by better scores in multiple SKT subtests compared to placebo. The results were statistically significant across several cognitive domains.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing coronary bypass surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and side effects of intravenous piracetam versus dimenhydrinate in treating acute peripheral vertigo in emergency department patients.
results_summary: Piracetam was found to be as effective as dimenhydrinate in treating acute vertigo but had about half the side effects, with drowsiness being the most common. The study concluded that piracetam could be more frequently used due to its better safety profile and effectiveness for both acute and chronic vertigo.
population_specificity: 200 patients aged 18-70 diagnosed with peripheral vertigo in an emergency department setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of piracetam on cognitive, motor, and endogenous defense functions in a rat model of cerebral global ischemic/reperfusion injury.
results_summary: Piracetam improved neurological and histopathological alterations, reduced water content and infarct size, but did not significantly restore or prevent impaired endogenous defense functions compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Rats subjected to bilateral common carotid artery occlusion (BCCAO) for 30 minutes followed by 24-hour reperfusion.
study_duration: Intervention duration not specified (assessment occurred after 24-hour reperfusion).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the metabolic pathways of piracetam in human liver microsomes and identify cytochrome P450 isoforms responsible for its metabolism.
results_summary: The study identified 2-(2-oxopyrrolidin-1-yl) acetic acid (M1) as the sole metabolite of piracetam in human liver microsomes and developed a validated method for detecting M1 in rat plasma for pharmacokinetic studies. Computer modeling suggested additional potential metabolites, but only M1 was detected experimentally.
population_specificity: Human liver microsomes and rat plasma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piracetam has anti-nociceptive (pain-relieving) effects and to explore its mechanisms of action in inflammatory pain models.
results_summary: Piracetam reduced pain-like behavior in multiple inflammatory pain models, diminished hyperalgesia, and inhibited cytokine production and oxidative stress, demonstrating analgesic activity dependent on these mechanisms.
population_specificity: Not specified (animal models inferred from methods).
effective_dosage: Not specified (dose-dependent effects noted but exact amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of piracetam in rotenone-induced Parkinsonism in rats, focusing on motor performance, biochemical markers, and histopathological changes.
results_summary: Piracetam significantly reversed locomotor deficits, increased striatal dopamine levels, and reduced TNF-α production in rotenone-treated rats, demonstrating neuroprotective effects.
population_specificity: Male rats with rotenone-induced Parkinsonism.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but rotenone was administered over 6 doses (48-hour intervals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of piracetam (40mg/kg/day) in preventing and controlling breath-holding spells (BHS) in children.
results_summary: Piracetam showed an 81% response rate after one month and 91% control of BHS by the end of the study, significantly outperforming placebo (16%). No significant difference in side effects was observed between the groups.
population_specificity: 150 children (86 boys) aged 6-24 months with severe breath-holding spells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piracetam mimics the neuroprotective and antihypoxic effects of the endogenous cyclic dipeptide cycloprolylglycine (CPG).
results_summary: CPG showed antihypoxic activity at 0.5 and 1.0 mg/kg in outbred and BALB/c mice but not in C57B1/6 mice. Neuroprotective effects were observed at concentrations of 10^(-5) to 10^(-8) M when administered 24 hours before toxin exposure, supporting the hypothesis that piracetam is a CPG mimetic.
population_specificity: Outbred mice, BALB/c mice, C57B1/6 mice, and human neuroblastoma SH-SY5Y cells.
effective_dosage: 0.5 and 1.0 mg/kg (i.p.) for antihypoxic activity; 10^(-5) to 10^(-8) M for neuroprotective effects.
study_duration: Treatment was administered 24 hours before toxin introduction for neuroprotective effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the histological effects of piracetam, dexamethasone, and memantine on cellular apoptosis caused by cisplatin ototoxicity in rats.
results_summary: Piracetam reduced the apoptosis rate, but the effect was not statistically significant. Dexamethasone and memantine showed significant effects, making them superior to piracetam in reducing cisplatin-induced ototoxicity.
population_specificity: 36 rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of piracetam and liothyronine on memory subscales (orientation, personal information, mental control) in patients undergoing ECT.
results_summary: Piracetam showed no significant difference compared to placebo or liothyronine in personal information, orientation, or mental control. Memory changes due to ECT were limited to orientation, but piracetam did not demonstrate superior efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients aged 20-45 undergoing ECT (n=60).
study_duration: From first ECT session until 1 month after the last session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of piracetam on method of delivery and perinatal morbidity in cases of suspected fetal distress during labor.
results_summary: Piracetam showed a trend toward reducing the need for cesarean section but did not demonstrate statistically significant differences in neonatal morbidity or Apgar scores compared to placebo. The authors concluded there was insufficient evidence to evaluate its use for fetal distress.
population_specificity: 96 women with suspected fetal distress during labor.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of piracetam on reducing death and disability in people with acute, presumed ischemic stroke.
results_summary: Piracetam was associated with a non-significant increase in death at one month, though this trend disappeared after correcting for baseline stroke severity differences. Limited data showed no difference in functional outcome, dependence, or proportion of patients dead or dependent between treatment and control groups.
population_specificity: Adults aged 40-85 with acute, presumed ischemic stroke, with both sexes equally represented.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of Piracetam on cognitive impairment in patients with contrasting psychiatric backgrounds.
results_summary: One patient with organic amnestic syndrome showed significant improvement, while another with organic personality change and a family history of mental illness experienced worsening behavioral problems after Piracetam use. The study highlights caution in prescribing Piracetam to those with psychiatric histories.
population_specificity: Patients with cognitive impairment, including one with organic amnestic syndrome and another with organic personality change and a family history of mental illness.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of piracetam in treating breath-holding spells (BHS) in children.
results_summary: Piracetam significantly reduced the number of BHS attacks compared to placebo (p < 0.001), with no reported side effects during the study. The median number of attacks/month declined from 5.5 to 1 in the piracetam group, while the placebo group showed no significant change.
population_specificity: Forty children with breath-holding spells, divided into two groups (piracetam and placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of piracetam against LPS-induced oxidative stress and DNA damage in leukocytes and macrophages.
results_summary: Piracetam pretreatment significantly protected against LPS-induced increases in ROS levels and DNA damage in both in vivo and ex vivo experiments, demonstrating its salutary effect on oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Sprague Dawley rats, isolated rat blood leukocytes, and rat macrophage cell line J774A.1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 6 months of piracetam treatment improves post-stroke aphasia compared to placebo.
results_summary: Piracetam showed no significant benefit over placebo for most clinical parameters and aphasia scores, except for a slight improvement in auditory comprehension. The study concluded that piracetam has no clear beneficial effect on post-stroke language disorders.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with first-ever ischemic strokes and severe aphasia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of piracetam on flap survival, ischemia-reperfusion injury, and VEGF expression in a rat model.
results_summary: Piracetam significantly reduced necrosis area in both ischemic and nonischemic flaps and increased VEGF expression in ischemia-reperfusion-induced flaps, though blood flow rates did not differ significantly between treated and untreated groups.
population_specificity: 36 rats in an unipedicled epigastric flap model.
effective_dosage: Not specified (administered 30 minutes before reperfusion and postoperatively for 7 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piracetam could improve mitochondrial function and mitigate the detrimental effects of beta-amyloid peptide (Abeta) in brain cells, particularly in the context of Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: Piracetam improved mitochondrial function in PC12 cells and dissociated brain cells exposed to Abeta(1-42), reduced soluble Abeta load in transgenic mice, and enhanced neurite outgrowth in PC12 cells. It also counteracted oxidative stress-induced Abeta production in HEK cells.
population_specificity: PC12 and HEK cell lines, dissociated brain cells from young and aged NMRI mice, and mice transgenic for mutant human amyloid precursor protein (APP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the structural binding mechanisms of piracetam on AMPA receptor subtypes GluA2 and GluA3 to understand its potential as an allosteric modulator.
results_summary: Piracetam binds to multiple sites along the dimer interface of AMPA receptors with low occupation, including a unique binding site that may be important for designing new allosteric regulators. The binding differs significantly from aniracetam, which binds symmetrically at the dimer interface center.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on receptor subtypes)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical outcomes, pharmacology, and safety of piracetam and its derivatives for various CNS disorders, focusing on evidence from the past 10 years.
results_summary: Piracetam showed neuroprotective effects during coronary bypass surgery and effectiveness for cognitive disorders of cerebrovascular/traumatic origin, but limited long-term benefits for mild cognitive impairment. It had a stronger effect on lowering depression and anxiety than improving memory and showed benefits as add-on therapy for myoclonus epilepsy and tardive dyskinesia.
population_specificity: Patients with CNS disorders (cognition/memory, epilepsy, neurodegenerative diseases, stroke/ischemia, stress, and anxiety).
interactions: Additive beneficial effect noted when combined with a vasodilator drug.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the neuroprotective potential of piracetam, silymarin, and protocatechuic acid ethyl ester (PCA) in focal ischemic rats.
results_summary: Piracetam improved behavioral and histopathological changes, reduced water content, and decreased infarct size, but did not significantly affect biochemical markers like silymarin and PCA.
population_specificity: Focal ischemic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piracetam could reverse cognitive dysfunction and oxidative stress induced by propoxur in the brain.
results_summary: Piracetam (400mg/kg/d) effectively reversed propoxur-induced cognitive deficits and oxidative stress, as evidenced by improved step-down latency, reduced transfer latency, and normalized brain MDA and NP-SH levels.
population_specificity: Animal model (specific species not mentioned in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piracetam, alone or in combination with acyclovir, provided additional benefits in treating idiopathic sudden hearing loss compared to standard combined treatment.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in hearing improvement between groups receiving piracetam, acyclovir, or their combination compared to standard treatment alone, concluding no additional benefit from these drugs.
population_specificity: 81 patients (44 males, 37 females; mean age 40.4 years) with idiopathic sudden hearing loss.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of general anesthesia on children's memory and evaluate the effectiveness of piracetam in preventing postoperative cognitive dysfunction.
results_summary: The study found that general anesthesia impaired memory, particularly long-term memory, in children. Intravenous piracetam administration improved cognitive function postoperatively.
population_specificity: Children undergoing various surgical procedures under general anesthesia.
study_duration: Intervention was administered once postoperatively; cognitive function was assessed over 10 consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of piracetam as a prophylactic treatment for severe breath-holding spells (BHS) in children.
results_summary: Piracetam was effective in completely eliminating spells in 81% of children and reducing frequency/intensity in 9%. Prophylaxis was administered for a mean duration of 5 months.
population_specificity: Children aged 4 weeks to 5 years (mean 17 months) diagnosed with severe BHS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of piracetam, alone and in combination with antiepileptic drugs, in treating action myoclonus in a patient with Lance-Adams syndrome.
results_summary: A lower dose of piracetam (15 g/day) combined with valproate sodium and clonazepam was ineffective, but increasing the dose to 21 g/day significantly improved freezing gait and walking ability, along with reduced cortical hyperexcitability. The study concluded that piracetam's efficacy in treating action myoclonus is dose-dependent.
population_specificity: A 17-year-old female with Lance-Adams syndrome caused by anoxic encephalopathy.
interactions: Combined with valproate sodium and clonazepam.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic effects of atomoxetine and piracetam in children with ADHD.
results_summary: Piracetam showed high effectiveness in treating ADHD, though its therapeutic effect was less pronounced and took longer to manifest compared to atomoxetine. Both treatments were more effective than no pharmacological therapy.
population_specificity: Children aged 6 to 13 years with ADHD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of piracetam on brain tissue and serum nitric oxide levels in dogs subjected to hemorrhagic shock.
results_summary: Piracetam improved blood pressure and pulse rates more than saline treatment alone and showed greater recovery in brain damage compared to the control group, though no correlation with nitric oxide levels was found.
population_specificity: Dogs subjected to hemorrhagic shock.
study_duration: 180 minutes (measurements taken at 60, 120, and 180 minutes post-intervention)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of piracetam in treating cognitive and motor impairments in adolescents with a history of moderate to severe closed craniocerebral trauma.
results_summary: Piracetam demonstrated positive therapeutic effects on higher mental functions (memory, attention, executive) and motor coordination, as well as improvements in the speed of cognitive and motor operations compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 12-18 years with a history of moderate to severe closed craniocerebral trauma occurring 1.5-5 years prior to the study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the genotype-dependent effects of neonatal piracetam administration on audiogenic seizure susceptibility in mice.
results_summary: Piracetam reduced seizure intensity in DBA/2J mice but increased it in CBA and 101/HY strains, indicating genotype-dependent effects. The study found no uniform efficacy across different mouse strains.
population_specificity: Neonatal DBA/2J, 101/HY, and CBA/Lac/Sto mice (2-7 days old).
study_duration: Single administration, effects assessed at 1 month of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the early effect of piracetam combined with steroids in treating acute acoustic trauma (AAT) in soldiers exposed to intense gunfire noise.
results_summary: The study found that 69% of patients showed hearing improvement (complete or partial recovery) after one month of treatment, with the highest recovery rate (65%) in the group treated within the first hour. The immediate onset of treatment (group A) resulted in statistically better hearing thresholds compared to delayed treatment groups.
population_specificity: Young soldiers exposed to intense gunfire noise (G3 rifle).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of piracetam in treating cognitive and motor function impairments in adolescents with moderate to severe closed traumatic brain injury.
