results_summary: The study demonstrated positive therapeutic effects of piracetam on cognitive functions (memory, attention, executive functions) and motor functions (coordination), as well as improvements in the speed of cognitive and motor performance.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 12-18 years with a history of moderate to severe closed traumatic brain injury occurring 1.5-5 years prior.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of high-dose piracetam in improving gait ataxia in patients with autosomal dominant cerebellar ataxia.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant improvement in patients' total score on the International Cooperative Ataxia Rating Scale, particularly in posture and gait disturbances. The results suggest high-dose piracetam may reduce disability by improving gait ataxia.
population_specificity: Eight patients with autosomal dominant cerebellar ataxia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Piracetam on memory impairment, neuronal damage, and synaptic plasticity in rats with chronic cerebral hypoperfusion.
results_summary: Piracetam improved memory impairment, increased hippocampal amino acid content, and reduced neuronal damage in rats with induced cerebral hypoperfusion. It also attenuated deficits in long-term potentiation and reduced overexpression of apoptosis-related proteins (BAX and P53).
population_specificity: Chronic cerebral hypoperfused rats (bilateral common carotid artery occlusion model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of piracetam on NMDA and nACh receptor binding sites in mice with high (EH) and low (EL) exploratory efficacy.
results_summary: Piracetam increased NMDA receptor binding sites by 70% in EL mice but decreased nACh receptor density in both EL (55%) and EH (40%) mice. Meclofenoxate also reduced nACh receptor density but increased NMDA receptor binding sites in EH mice.
population_specificity: Outbred ICR strain mice divided into high (EH) and low (EL) exploratory efficacy groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of high-dose piracetam in treating children with Kozhevnikov epilepsy syndrome (epilepsia partialis continua).
results_summary: Piracetam reduced myoclonus frequency by 75% in half the patients and stopped it completely in the other half, decreased focal clonic seizures, and improved neurological and cognitive functioning in most patients. Clinical improvement lasted 1-2 months post-treatment.
population_specificity: 6 children aged 9-16 years with Kozhevnikov epilepsy.
effective_dosage: Mean dose of 1g/kg/day (up to 35 g/day) intravenously.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of piracetam as a positive modulator of AMPA-sensitive glutamate receptors in improving symptoms of autistic disorder when combined with risperidone.
results_summary: The study found that piracetam combined with risperidone significantly improved Aberrant Behavior Checklist-Community (ABC-C) Rating Scale scores compared to placebo plus risperidone, with a statistically significant difference between the two groups. The results suggest synergistic effects of combining piracetam with atypical antipsychotics in treating autism.
population_specificity: 40 children aged 3-11 years with a DSM IV clinical diagnosis of autism and severely disruptive symptoms.
effective_dosage: Piracetam was titrated up to 800 mg/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of opiatergic mechanisms in the antiamnestic effects of piracetam and its interaction with morphine-induced effects in mice.
results_summary: Piracetam reversed drug- or electrically-induced amnesia but decreased the antinociceptive effect of morphine, suggesting opiatergic system involvement in its antiamnestic action.
population_specificity: Mice
interactions: Interaction with morphine noted (decreased antinociceptive effect)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to reexamine the efficacy of oral piracetam in reducing symptoms of tardive dyskinesia in patients with schizophrenia or schizo-affective disorders.
results_summary: Piracetam significantly improved symptoms of tardive dyskinesia, with notable reductions in clinical global impression, tardive parkinsonism, and tardive dyskinesia subscale scores compared to placebo. The placebo group showed minimal improvement or slight deterioration.
population_specificity: 40 DSM-IV schizophrenic and schizo-affective patients with DSM-IV-TR tardive dyskinesia.
study_duration: 4 weeks per treatment phase (total 9 weeks including washout)

study_goal: To assess the effectiveness of piracetam for reducing the incidence of painful sickle cell disease crises.
results_summary: The study found insufficient reliable evidence to support piracetam's routine use for preventing painful sickle cell crises, with mixed and incomplete data on pain reduction and no significant difference in hospitalization days. Participant satisfaction was reported but not detailed, and adverse effects were minimal (only one case of dizziness).
population_specificity: People of all ages and both sexes with sickle cell disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Piracetam on learning, memory, brain metabolism, membrane fluidity, and its potential therapeutic benefits in disorders like dementia, vertigo, myoclonus, and stroke.
results_summary: Piracetam improved learning, memory, and brain metabolism, enhanced membrane fluidity, protected against hypoxia, increased red cell deformability, normalized platelet aggregation, and demonstrated antithrombotic, neuroprotective, and rheological properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of mechanisms and potential applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of piracetam on reducing death and disability in people with acute presumed ischaemic stroke.
results_summary: Piracetam was associated with a non-significant increase in death at one month, though this trend disappeared after correcting for stroke severity imbalance. Limited data showed no difference in functional outcomes, dependency, or proportion of patients dead or dependent between treatment and control groups.
population_specificity: Adults aged 40-85 with acute presumed ischaemic stroke, both sexes equally represented.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piracetam improves mitochondrial dysfunction caused by oxidative stress and aging.
results_summary: Piracetam improved mitochondrial membrane potential and ATP production in PC12 cells and dissociated brain cells, particularly in aged animals, and reduced caspase 9 activity. It also lowered elevated antioxidant enzyme activities in aged mouse brains.
population_specificity: PC12 cells, dissociated brain cells from mice (young and aged).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Piracetam as a treatment for tardive dyskinesia (TD) in patients receiving antipsychotic therapy.
results_summary: The abstract suggests possible improvements in TD symptoms with Piracetam, though the evidence is not detailed or conclusive. The study reviews multiple pharmacological agents, including Piracetam, but does not provide specific outcome data for it.
population_specificity: Patients with tardive dyskinesia receiving antipsychotic treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of piracetam in treating postoperative cognitive impairment after coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).
results_summary: Piracetam showed a statistically significant improvement in cognitive function six weeks after CABG in the per-protocol population and a trend toward significance in the intent-to-treat population. Anxiety decreased in both groups, but no significant cognitive improvement was observed in the placebo group.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) (n = 98).
effective_dosage: Intravenous (150 mg/kg daily; 300 mg/kg on the day of surgery) followed by oral (12 g/day).
study_duration: From the day before surgery to 6 weeks after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a one-year personalized plant-based dietary intervention could reduce DNA damage in post-surgery, non-metastatic colorectal cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found a significant 32% reduction in DNA base oxidation in the intervention group compared to the control group, but no significant effect on DNA strand breaks. Adherence to a plant-based dietary pattern may reduce DNA base oxidation in these patients.
population_specificity: Post-surgery, non-metastatic colorectal cancer patients aged 50-80 years (stage I-III).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine metabolomic profiles in response to the portfolio diet (a cholesterol-lowering plant-based diet) compared to a control vegetarian diet and a control diet with a statin.
results_summary: The study found significant changes in metabolites (e.g., glycerophosphocholines, triacylglycerols) associated with the portfolio diet, reflecting its plant-based nature and cholesterol-lowering effects. Fifty-two metabolites consistently changed in the same direction across both RCTs.
population_specificity: Adults with high LDL-C (>4.1 mmol/L), aged 58.4 ± 8.6 years (first RCT) and 61.0 ± 9.6 years (second RCT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether feed efficiency-related traits in Pacific whiteleg shrimp exhibit diet-specific genetic variations and genotype-by-diet interactions when comparing a plant-based (fishmeal-free) diet to a fishmeal-based diet.
results_summary: The plant-based diet resulted in significantly higher residual feed intake (RFI) and lower average daily weight gain (ADG) compared to the fishmeal-based diet, indicating reduced yields and potential profitability impacts. Genetic correlations suggested genotype × diet interactions, particularly for ADG, highlighting the need for selective breeding to improve feed efficiency in plant-based diets.
population_specificity: Pacific whiteleg shrimp (Penaeus vannamei)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether plant-based diets associate with frailty risk in older adults and whether this association is moderated by sex and income.
results_summary: A healthful plant-based diet (hPDI) was associated with lower odds of frailty, while an unhealthful plant-based diet (uPDI) was linked to higher frailty risk, particularly among men with low income. The association for uPDI was moderated by income and sex, but not for hPDI.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 55.48 ± 7.87) from the UK Biobank cohort (n = 73,180).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how increasing plant food diversity impacts metabolomic, microbiome, and clinical parameters in individuals with moderate chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The high-diversity plant-based diet (HDPD) improved diet quality, reduced renal acid load, decreased symptom burden, and shifted the gut microbiome toward beneficial metabolites, while the low-diversity diet reduced microbial diversity. Uremic toxin reductions were significant in responders with poorer kidney function.
population_specificity: 25 Australian adults with stage 3-4 CKD.
effective_dosage: ≥30 unique plant foods weekly (HDPD) vs. ≤15 unique plant foods weekly (LDPD).
study_duration: 6 weeks per diet, with a 4-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a whole foods, plant-based (WFPB) diet, combined with physical activity and stress management, on cardiovascular risk factors in military veterans with atherosclerotic heart disease and/or type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The intervention led to statistically significant improvements in waist circumference, systolic blood pressure, LDL cholesterol, fasting glucose, and hemoglobin A1c. Participants with type 2 diabetes showed additional improvements in hemoglobin A1c and diastolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Military veterans (mean age 69.2 years, 97% male) with atherosclerotic heart disease and/or type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a defined, plant-based diet, alone or combined with alternative therapies, could improve outcomes in Stage C and D HFrEF patients who failed guideline-directed medical therapy.
results_summary: The study found that a plant-based diet, sometimes combined with alternative therapies, improved LVEF and RVSP, reduced medication needs and body weight, and enhanced quality of life in HFrEF patients.
population_specificity: Seven patients with Stage C and D heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) who failed guideline-directed medical therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a plant-based diet on gut microbiota composition and inflammation in Crohn's Disease patients and assess the utility of trnL gene sequencing for monitoring dietary adherence.
results_summary: The study found that a plant-based diet increased microbial diversity, boosted key gut-health-associated genera (e.g., Faecalibacterium and Bacteroides), and reduced fecal calprotectin levels, indicating decreased intestinal inflammation. TrnL sequencing proved more accurate than self-reported food diaries in assessing plant residue diversity.
population_specificity: Fourteen Crohn's Disease patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a 16-week whole-food plant-based diet (WPBD) on periodontal parameters in patients with increased cardiometabolic risk.
results_summary: The WPBD group showed a reduction in periodontal inflamed surface area (PISA) and matrix-metalloproteinase-8 (MMP-8) levels, while the control group saw an increase in PISA. Saliva pH increased only in the WPBD group, but changes within groups were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 36 participants with increased cardiometabolic risk from a randomized clinical trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine associations between healthful and unhealthful plant-based dietary patterns and all-cause mortality risk in individuals with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: Higher adherence to a healthful plant-based diet was associated with a 34% lower mortality risk, while an unhealthful plant-based diet was linked to a 52% higher risk. Specific food groups like wholegrains reduced mortality risk, whereas refined grains and sugar-sweetened beverages increased it.
population_specificity: 4807 UK Biobank participants with CKD at baseline.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary patterns assessed via repeated 24-hour dietary assessments).

study_goal: To investigate the feasibility of a plant-based diet intervention for Crohn's disease patients and assess its impact on disease activity and quality of life.
results_summary: The study found a clinically positive trend in symptom improvement (HBI and IBDQ scores) but no statistically significant effects. Adverse effects included decreased protein intake and slight muscle mass reduction.
population_specificity: Outpatients with Crohn's disease on biological therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a plant-based diet is associated with improved survival outcomes in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer (CRC).
results_summary: The study found that higher adherence to a plant-based diet, particularly one rich in healthful plant foods, was associated with better overall survival and progression-free survival in metastatic CRC patients. No significant association was observed for unhealthful plant-based diets.
population_specificity: Patients with metastatic colorectal cancer (n=1284).
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary indices based on food frequency questionnaires).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the impact of plant-based diets on metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) and assess their potential benefits and challenges.
results_summary: The study found that plant-based diets can improve weight control, metabolic health, and coexisting diseases, but challenges like adherence difficulties and nutritional deficiencies persist.
population_specificity: Individuals with metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether clinically healthy adult dogs could maintain health on a complete and well-balanced canine plant-based diet (K9PBN) over twelve months compared to a meat-based diet.
results_summary: The study found that clinically healthy adult dogs maintained health, as evidenced by physical exams, blood tests, plasma amino acids, serum vitamins, and cardiac biomarkers, when fed commercial K9PBN for twelve months. No adverse health outcomes were reported, suggesting nutritional equivalence to a meat-based diet.
population_specificity: Clinically healthy adult dogs living in households in Los Angeles County, California.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and feasibility of a plant-based diet (PBD) in hyperkalemic chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients receiving the potassium binder sodium zirconium cyclosilicate (SZC).
results_summary: The study found that PBD improved dietary quality and increased healthy food intake while maintaining stable plasma potassium levels within normal ranges for most patients. No episodes of severe hyperkalemia or hypokalemia occurred, and improvements were noted in fiber intake, dietary quality, and some aspects of quality of life.
population_specificity: Hyperkalemic patients with CKD stage 4-5 not on dialysis (n=26).
effective_dosage: Not specified (weekly food basket for PBD, SZC titrated to achieve normokalemia).
study_duration: 6 weeks (3 weeks low-protein low-potassium diet + SZC, 3 weeks PBD + SZC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of cholesterol supplementation in a plant-based diet on the intestinal barriers (physical, chemical, immune, and biological) of GIFT strain tilapia.
results_summary: The study found that supplementing 1.2% cholesterol in a plant-based diet improved intestinal structure, tight junction function, enzyme activity, reduced inflammation-related gene expression, and enhanced microbiota composition in tilapia. The 1.2% dosage showed the most significant benefits compared to other tested levels.
population_specificity: GIFT strain tilapia (Oreochromis niloticus) with an initial mean weight of 6.08 ± 0.12 g.
effective_dosage: 0.6%, 1.2%, and 1.8% cholesterol added to the plant-based diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between plant-based diet index (PDI) and COVID-19 severity, specifically whether higher PDI scores correlated with lower hospitalization rates.
results_summary: The study found that higher overall PDI and healthy PDI scores were associated with significantly lower odds of hospitalization in COVID-19 patients, suggesting a protective effect. Adjusted odds ratios indicated a 58% and 55% reduction in hospitalization risk per 10-unit increase in overall PDI and healthy PDI, respectively.
population_specificity: 141 patients with confirmed COVID-19, categorized into severe (hospitalized) and non-severe (treated at home) cases.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary intake assessed via food frequency questionnaire).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify barriers adults aged 18 to 65 in high-income countries face when adopting a plant-based diet (PBD) and map these barriers to behavior change strategies.
results_summary: The study identified 40 barriers grouped into 11 themes, with nutritional intake/requirements, habits, and lack of knowledge being the most prominent. Education interventions and communication/marketing policies were suggested to address these barriers.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18 to 65 living in high-income countries.

study_goal: To evaluate whether a 12-week learning management system combining nutritional intervention with emotional intelligence education could improve cardiometabolic outcomes in individuals with elevated BMI.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in BMI and LDL levels at program completion and 6-month follow-up, along with improvements in secondary outcomes like energy/fatigue, self-regard, decision-making, and stress management.
population_specificity: 37 adult volunteers with BMI greater than 25.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a plant-based diet (PBD) could serve as an effective dietary intervention for inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), countering the negative effects of the current westernized diet.
results_summary: The study found that a PBD significantly improved remission rates in both Crohn's disease (96%) and severe ulcerative colitis (76%), with relapse-free outcomes in 52% of Crohn's disease patients at 10-year follow-up. Additionally, PBD alone induced remission in one-third of mild ulcerative colitis cases without medication.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), including Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, treated on an inpatient basis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary intervention without quantified dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a lifestyle intervention focusing on a healthy plant-based diet on risk markers for obesity and related metabolic conditions.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in dietary quality, body weight, BMI, waist circumference, cholesterol levels, blood pressure, and other metabolic markers after 10 weeks and sustained reductions in weight and LDL cholesterol after 16 months. Increases in adherence to a healthful plant-based diet were associated with these improvements.
population_specificity: Mostly middle-aged and elderly participants from the general population (n = 115).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a short-term whole-food plant-based (WFPB) diet could reduce daytime sleepiness in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant mean decrease of 3.8 points on the Epworth Sleepiness Scale (ESS) after switching from a standard Western diet to a WFPB diet, suggesting reduced daytime sleepiness. The results indicate that a WFPB diet may be a viable intervention for this symptom.
population_specificity: 14 patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore hypertension management among Indonesian farmers using a plant-based diet (PBD), assess its acceptability, and evaluate the effectiveness of a community-based nursing program for hypertension treatment.
results_summary: The study expects to develop a PBD model for hypertension management, assess its acceptability among farmers, and implement a community-based nursing program. Results indicate potential benefits but require local validation for broader application.
population_specificity: Farmers in Indonesia with hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of a whole food plant-based diet on managing multiple sclerosis symptoms in patients who stopped disease-modifying therapies.
results_summary: Two patients with multiple sclerosis who adopted a whole food plant-based diet experienced only one flare-up each over 5-6 years after discontinuing medication, suggesting potential benefits of dietary intervention.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (specifically two case reports).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of a plant-based diet (PBD) in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and assess its role as part of a first-line therapy.
results_summary: The study reported a 96% remission rate in Crohn's disease (CD) and a relapse-free course in 52% of CD patients when PBD was combined with infliximab. The authors assert that PBD is anti-inflammatory and highly recommended for IBD.
population_specificity: Patients with newly developed Crohn's disease (CD) and severe ulcerative colitis (UC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the associations between adherence to a plant-based diet and cognitive aging in older adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant associations between overall, healthful, or unhealthful plant-based diet adherence and cognitive function or change. However, a potential benefit was observed in individuals with higher fish consumption (≥0.93 portions/week).
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged ≥65 years.
interactions: Fish consumption influenced the association between plant-based diet adherence and cognitive functioning.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of a diet change to veganism on the strength performance of strength-trained individuals.
results_summary: The study found no difference in absolute and relative strength performance (leg press and bench press) after switching to a vegan diet. Protein intake decreased significantly and was lower than current recommendations for athletes, but total calorie and carbohydrate intake showed only small treatment effects.
population_specificity: 15 omnivorous, strength-trained individuals (10 completed the study).
study_duration: 16 weeks (8 weeks omnivorous diet, 8 weeks vegan diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a Whole Food Plant-based (WFPB) diet in improving weight and biochemical markers of disease in a clinical setting.
results_summary: Adoption of a WFPB diet led to significant weight loss (4.3 kg), reduced total cholesterol and triglycerides, and increased HDL levels. The study demonstrated clinically meaningful improvements in metabolic health markers.
population_specificity: 17 participants (average age 59 years, 59% female) with conditions like hyperlipidemia, hypertension, coronary artery disease, fatty liver disease, and diabetes mellitus.
study_duration: Median attendance of 3 group sessions (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between the plant-based diet index (PDI) and type 2 diabetes (T2D) risk in a Chinese population, particularly examining differences based on cardiovascular risk levels.
results_summary: Higher PDI scores were associated with significantly reduced T2D risk in the total population, high cardiovascular risk group (HCRP), and non-high cardiovascular risk group (non-HCRP). The protective effect was stronger in subgroups like the elderly, men, and those with lower BMI.
population_specificity: 50,694 Chinese residents aged 35-75, divided into high cardiovascular risk (HCRP; n=17,255) and non-high cardiovascular risk (non-HCRP; n=33,439) groups.
effective_dosage: Not specified (PDI calculated from food frequency questionnaire).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different messaging strategies (addition vs. replacement of meat with legumes, with or without dynamic norms) influence short-term and long-term legume and meat consumption in promoting a plant-based diet.
results_summary: Addition messages increased legume consumption more than replacement messages in the short term, especially among those with negative evaluations of flexitarians. Long-term legume consumption increased only when addition messages were combined with dynamic norms. Replacement messages reduced meat consumption more effectively in the short term, while replacement messages with dynamic norms were more effective in the long term.
population_specificity: 428 volunteers (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of plant-based diets (PBDs) as a treatment for obesity and their benefits in managing other non-communicable diseases like type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that PBDs can lead to weight loss, improved cardiovascular health, lower blood pressure, and better glucose metabolism, though many RCTs were short-term, and longer-term studies are needed.
population_specificity: Obese patients and individuals with non-communicable diseases like type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the nutrient profiles and cardiovascular health effects of a whole-food plant-based diet (PBD) versus an omnivorous diet in individuals with cardiovascular risk factors.
results_summary: The PBD group showed lower energy density, cholesterol, saturated fat, and salt intake, along with higher fiber consumption. It also led to significant improvements in body weight, BMI, waist circumference, HbA1c, and fasting blood glucose compared to the control group, though vitamin B12 deficiency was noted in the PBD group.
population_specificity: Individuals with cardiovascular risk factors (n = 36 in PBD group, n = 34 in control group).
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary intervention included eight 90-minute group meetings and two 120-minute cooking sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining infliximab and a plant-based diet as first-line therapy could improve long-term relapse-free rates in patients with Crohn's disease.
results_summary: The study found that infliximab and a plant-based diet resulted in relapse-free rates of 79%, 66%, 57%, and 52% at 1, 2, 3, and 4 years, respectively, with no further reduction up to 10 years. The plant-based diet score significantly improved over time, and surgical rates remained relatively low (12% at 5 years, 19% at 10 years).
population_specificity: Newly diagnosed adult patients with Crohn's disease in Japan.
effective_dosage: Not specified (plant-based diet only, no dosage mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a plant-based diet (PBD) versus a traditional diet (TD) on plasma levels of TMAO and its precursors (choline and betaine) in healthy adult dogs.
results_summary: The study found that dogs consuming a PBD had significantly lower plasma choline and betaine levels compared to those on a TD, but no difference in plasma TMAO levels was detected. The PBD had lower betaine content than the TD, while choline content was similar in both diets.
population_specificity: Sixteen healthy adult mixed breed dogs from a university colony.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding whole eggs to a plant-based diet (PBD) would protect against oxidative stress and low-grade inflammation in individuals with metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: The study found that adding eggs to a PBD did not negatively affect inflammation or oxidative stress and may provide additional protection against MetS biomarkers, such as reducing plasma malondialdehyde (MDA) concentrations. Eggs were also more effective than egg substitutes in reversing MetS characteristics.
population_specificity: 24 men and women with metabolic syndrome (MetS).
effective_dosage: Two whole eggs with 70 g of spinach/day (EGG) or equivalent egg substitute with spinach (SUB) as breakfast.
study_duration: 4 weeks per intervention (with a 3-week washout between interventions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of plant-based diets on prostate cancer risk, oncologic outcomes, and general health/nutrition in at-risk men and patients with prostate cancer.
results_summary: Interventional studies showed improvements in short-term oncologic outcomes and general health, while observational studies indicated either protective or null associations between plant-based diets and prostate cancer risk, with vegan diets consistently showing favorable results.
population_specificity: Men at risk for prostate cancer, patients with prostate cancer (including those on active surveillance or with biochemical recurrence), and caregivers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between plant-based diet indices postdiagnosis and quality-of-life domains in individuals with nonmetastatic prostate cancer.
results_summary: A higher plant-based diet index was associated with better scores in sexual function, urinary irritation/obstruction, urinary incontinence, and hormonal/vitality. Healthful plant-based foods also showed associations with improved sexual and bowel function, urinary incontinence, and hormonal/vitality in age-adjusted analysis, though not in multivariable analysis.
population_specificity: 3,505 male participants with nonmetastatic prostate cancer from the Health Professionals Follow-Up Study (1986–2016).
study_duration: Median time from diagnosis/treatment to first quality-of-life questionnaire was 7.0 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of foot reflexology on pain and nausea among inpatients with cancer compared to traditional nursing care alone.
results_summary: Foot reflexology significantly decreased pain in cancer inpatients compared to traditional care, while effects on nausea were not statistically significant but showed some clinical relevance.
population_specificity: Adult cancer patients hospitalized on a 24-bed inpatient oncology unit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of foot and palm reflexology on respiratory distress in preterm infants receiving noninvasive ventilation.
results_summary: Reflexology massage, particularly palm reflexology, significantly improved oxygen saturation, respiratory rate, and respiratory distress scores in preterm infants compared to the control group. The effects were statistically significant after three days of intervention.
population_specificity: Preterm infants hospitalized in intensive care units with respiratory distress.
effective_dosage: 10-minute reflexology massage sessions, performed 6 times over 3 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether reflexology could reduce headache and muscle pain intensity in patients receiving electroconvulsive therapy (ECT).
results_summary: Reflexology significantly reduced the severity of headache and muscle pain in the intervention group compared to the control group, with notable differences observed at multiple time points post-intervention. The study concluded that reflexology is effective for pain reduction in ECT patients.
population_specificity: 56 patients with depression receiving ECT in a teaching hospital in Iran.
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of reflexology at reflex points.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of foot reflexology on ankle brachial index, diabetic peripheral neuropathy, and glycemic control in older adults with diabetes.
results_summary: Foot reflexology significantly improved diabetic peripheral neuropathy and glycemic control (reduced glycated hemoglobin A levels) in the experimental group compared to the control group, but had no significant effect on ankle brachial index. The effect sizes were medium for both outcomes.
population_specificity: Older adults (aged 65+) with diabetes in Turkey.
effective_dosage: Not specified (foot reflexology performed for 12 weeks).

study_goal: To determine the effect of foot reflexology on the sexual function of hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Foot reflexology significantly improved male orgasm function, sexual desire, and intercourse satisfaction in hemodialysis patients compared to sham massage, but no significant effects were observed for erectile function, overall satisfaction, or female sexual function.
population_specificity: 47 chronic hemodialysis patients (43 males, 5 females) referred to Imam Reza Hospital in Sirjan, Iran.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per session (15 minutes per foot), three times a week for four weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of reflexology and aromatherapy massage on the severity of restless legs syndrome (RLS) in female hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Reflexology did not appear to cause any significant reduction in RLS severity, while aromatherapy massage showed a reduction. The study concluded that aromatherapy massage, not reflexology, should be incorporated into routine care for these patients.
population_specificity: 105 female patients undergoing hemodialysis in an urban Iranian hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the benefits of foot reflexology as a complementary therapy for managing acute chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV) in patients with digestive or lung cancer.
results_summary: Foot reflexology significantly improved acute nausea severity and reduced antiemetic drug consumption, though it showed no significant impact on delayed nausea, vomiting, quality of life, or anxiety. No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with lung or digestive cancer undergoing platinum-based chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 30-minute foot reflexology sessions per chemotherapy cycle.
study_duration: Conducted between April 2018 and April 2020 (exact per-patient duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of reflexology and meditative practices in managing fatigue and other symptoms in cancer patients and their caregivers, evaluating different sequencing strategies.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences among the four decision rules for symptom management, except for lower symptom severity at week 8 when using reflexology alone compared to sequencing reflexology with meditative practices. Adding the other therapy for nonresponders after 4 weeks did not show additional benefits.
population_specificity: Patients with cancer and their informal caregivers.
study_duration: 12 weeks (initial 4-week intervention, with possible extension to 8 weeks for nonresponders).

study_goal: To determine if adding aromatherapy and foot reflexology to standard care improves pain and anxiety in cervical cancer patients undergoing brachytherapy.
results_summary: The intervention group showed equal or lower average pain and anxiety scores at all time points, with statistically significant reductions in anxiety post-reflexology.
population_specificity: 41 women with locally advanced cervical cancer receiving intracavitary brachytherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of foot reflexology for reducing symptoms of infantile colic, including crying duration and colic severity.
results_summary: The study found that foot reflexology significantly reduced Infant Colic Scale scores and daily crying duration compared to placebo, with infants in the reflexology group crying less and experiencing fewer symptoms post-treatment.
population_specificity: 45 infants diagnosed with infantile colic (20 in the reflexology group, 25 in the placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of foot reflexology massage on the incidence of delirium and sleep quality in patients undergoing cardiac surgery.
results_summary: Foot reflexology did not significantly reduce delirium or improve sleep quality, but it did decrease pain intensity in postoperative cardiac surgery patients. The odds ratio for delirium reduction was not statistically significant, and sleep quality differences between groups were negligible.
population_specificity: 60 patients undergoing CABG surgery, randomized into intervention and control groups.
effective_dosage: 15 minutes per foot, for two consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of a larger trial to determine the effect of foot reflexology on patients undergoing hospital-based haemodialysis, focusing on HRQOL and sleep quality.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in both physical and mental health components of HRQOL and sleep quality post-intervention, with positive patient reception and no disruption to haemodialysis routines.
population_specificity: Twenty patients undergoing hospital-based haemodialysis treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of foot reflexology massage on pruritus in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Foot reflexology massage significantly reduced itching or pruritus in hemodialysis patients (P < 0.001), with no significant difference in pruritus scores between groups before the intervention (P = 0.59). The control group also showed statistically significant changes in pruritus scores (P < 0.001).
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients with moderate-to-severe pruritus.
effective_dosage: Nine sessions of foot reflexology massage (3 days a week for 20 min per session, 10 min on each foot).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of reflexology based on Watson's theory of human caring on anxiety, depression, and quality of life in gynecological cancer patients.
results_summary: Reflexology significantly reduced anxiety and depression levels and improved quality of life in gynecological cancer patients. It also alleviated chemotherapy-related symptoms like fatigue, pain, insomnia, and loss of appetite, though some symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation) temporarily worsened two weeks post-intervention.
population_specificity: Gynecological cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
study_duration: October 2016 to June 2018 (exact intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether foot reflexology could effectively manage amnesia in patients undergoing electroconvulsive therapy (ECT).
results_summary: The study found that foot reflexology significantly improved recalling scores in the intervention group compared to the control group, suggesting it may be effective in managing post-ECT amnesia. The technique was described as simple, inexpensive, and non-invasive with few side effects.
population_specificity: 68 patients undergoing ECT who met the inclusion criteria.
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of foot reflexology per day.
